repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Social Protection Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Social and Protection
            Technical Assistance Project for Chile was satisfactory. The
            risk to development outcome was low or negligible, and the
            performance by both Bank and the borrower was satisfactory.
            The following were few of the lessons learned: (1) single
            initiative or program can serve as a practical and concrete
            base for the installation of broader social protection
            system which can be extended to cover other populations. (2)
            Bank financing can play a role in financing activities which
            once validated can be incorporated into the national budget;
            (3) integrated information system is critical in order to
            ensure that social programs reach those who need them the
            most, and to guard the system from falling prey to abuse.
            Without such a system social policies and interventions
            cannot be effectively targeted, monitored or evaluated; (4)
            the incorporation of the targeting instrument into the
            integrated social information platform was a powerful tool
            in the creation of a national registry of beneficiaries
            which in turn became a valuable tool for managing a network
            of social protection services; (5) high-quality
            administrative data bases can be an important source of
            information not only for the monitoring of social programs,
            but also their impact evaluation, particularly if they can
            be linked to survey data.

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Additional Financing for the Social
            Protection Technical Assistance Loan Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Additional
            Financing for the Social Protection Technical Assistance
            Loan Project are to support the efforts of the Government of
            Chile to implement Chile Soidario and lay the foundation of
            a national system of social protection. The Government has
            focused the resources available in the additional financing
            to reform the targeting instrument used for social programs,
            including improving controls over fraud and error, as well
            as supporting the design and implementation arrangements for
            the proposed Ingreso Etico which builds on the experience of
            Chile Solidario within the inter-institutional system of
            social protection. Support also has been provided to the
            evaluation of parental education activities which are part
            of the early childhood development initiative of Chile Crece
            Contigo. Project objectives continue to be achievable.
            Although the Chileans authorities recently requested the
            cancellation of US$1,398,000 of the grant, this has not
            affected the activities being carried out as the Government
            has compensated with the provision of national resources.
            Performance of the borrower and the implementing agency is
            satisfactory. There are no outstanding audit reports or
            audit reports unsatisfactory to the Bank or financial or
            procurement issues associated with the project. Neither this
            loan in particular, nor Chile is under suspension of
            disbursements. The extension is necessary to allow the
            Government of Chile to complete an activity associated with
            the assessment of a parental education intervention
            undertaken as part of Chile Crece Contigo. The timetable for
            the activity provided by the Borrower will allow completion
            and review of the results of the work.

Chile - Additional Financing for
            the Social Protection Technical Assistance Loan Project :
            restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Additional financing for the
            Scaling-up of the Social Protection Technical Assistance
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Additional
            financing for the Scaling-up of the Social Protection
            Technical Assistance Project are to support the efforts of
            the Government of Chile to implement Chile Solidario and lay
            the basis for a national system of social protection now
            including a subsystem for young children. The closing date
            for the project will be extended from August 31, 2011 until
            December 31, 2012. The extension is necessary to allow the
            Government of Chile sufficient time to complete
            disbursements under the loan. Utilization of the resources
            of the additional financing has been delayed due to the
            change of Government, the major role that the executing
            agency (Ministry of Planning) had in responding to the
            emergency related to the earthquake early last year, as well
            as initial unfamiliarity with the Bank and its procedures.
            The ownership of the Government has been demonstrated by
            their preparation of an action plan to fully utilize the
            additional financing loan resources by the end of 2012. This
            will be the first extension of the additional financing loan.

display_title.display_title:
Chile - Additional financing for
            the Scaling-up of the Social Protection Technical Assistance
            Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!: Social protection in Latin America and the Caribbean

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about the
            social protection in Latin America and the Caribbean.
            Poverty and inequality are critical issues in growing
            economies and tend to pass from generation to generation in
            the same families. The poor and vulnerable were exposed to a
            wide range of risks and shocks that affected their current
            wellbeing and their longer-term prospects for rising out of
            poverty. To address these challenges, all countries need
            social safety nets both to protect the vulnerable from
            falling into poverty during crises and to help them
            transition out of poverty in the absence of larger crises.
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            has helped countries in Latin America and the Caribbean
            pioneer conditional cash transfers (CCTs) as a proven
            approach to helping people out of poverty. CCT programs have
            implemented novel approaches to targeting the poor,
            addressing gender issues, transferring funds, fostering
            social accountability, building error and fraud control
            systems, and strengthening governance. CCT programs have
            also used new technologies such as bank cards to facilitate
            payments and cell phones to send educational messages to
            recipients. They have linked clients to social services,
            helped obtain identity documents for marginalized groups,
            and promoted savings as a medium-term strategy to help CCT
            households out of poverty. CCTs supported by the IBRD in the
            last decade benefitted about 21 million households annually
            in Latin America and the Caribbean.

Transferencias monetarias condicionadas
            mejoran capital humano
